Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the step-parent needs to provide it
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Story: I was halfway through my shift as a subway operator when my phone buzzed with a message from my partner: “We’re out of groceries. Can you pick up some food? We’re short on cash again.” The weight of being a step-parent pressed on me—I knew the kids would be hungry tonight, and it was my responsibility to keep the household running. As I tried to focus on the tracks ahead, a shrill alarm blared through the control panel. The passenger emergency alarm. My heart raced. I glanced at the monitor and saw a crowd gathering around someone slumped on a seat. Protocol demanded I stop the train, call for medical help, and assist the passenger. But every minute I spent here meant less time to pick up groceries before the store closed, less chance to stretch our dwindling funds. My mind spun between the urgent needs of a stranger and the hungry faces waiting at home. I gripped the controls, torn between the duty to my passengers and the promise I’d made to my family.
